message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Neuro-Adaptive Optimized Control of Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems With State Constraints
Paper Abstract: This article proposes an adaptive neural network (NN) output feedback optimized control design for a class of strict-feedback nonlinear systems that contain unknown internal dynamics and the states that are immeasurable and constrained within some predefined compact sets. NNs are used to approximate the unknown internal dynamics, and an adaptive NN state observer is developed to estimate the immeasurable states. By constructing a barrier type of optimal cost functions for subsystems and employing an observer and the actor-critic architecture, the virtual and actual optimal controllers are developed under the framework of backstepping technique. In addition to ensuring the boundedness of all closed-loop signals, the proposed strategy can also guarantee that system states are confined within some preselected compact sets all the time. This is achieved by means of barrier Lyapunov functions which have been successfully applied to various kinds of nonlinear systems such as strict-feedback and pure-feedback dynamics. Besides, our developed optimal controller requires less conditions on system dynamics than some existing approaches concerning optimal control. The effectiveness of the proposed optimal control approach is eventually validated by numerical as well as practical examples.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Back mount - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back_mount"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Take back control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Take_Back_Control"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping is a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)It is one of several nonlinear control techniques that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

## How It Works

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized, and the stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.(no content)The process terminates when the final external control is reached, and this process is known as backstepping.

## Applications

Systems in strict-feedback form can be stabilized by recursive application of backstepping. This makes it particularly useful for designing controllers for complex nonlinear systems.

## Historical Contributions

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Backstepping is a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)It is one of several nonlinear control techniques that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

## How It Works

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized, and the stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.(no content)The process terminates when the final external control is reached, and this process is known as backstepping.

## Applications

Systems in strict-feedback form can be stabilized by recursive application of backstepping. This makes it particularly useful for designing controllers for complex nonlinear systems.

## Historical Contributions

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

I've completed the web search for "Neural Network". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Structure

Neurons in an artificial neural network are usually arranged into layers, with information passing from the first layer (the input layer) through one or more intermediate layers (the hidden layers) to the final layer (the output layer).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.

The search results also cover various specialized types of neural networks including convolutional neural networks (CNNs), graph neural networks (GNNs), spiking neural networks (SNNs), and feedback neural networks, along with their historical development dating back to early theoretical work in the 1800s and practical implementations in the mid-20th century.

Web search results for query: "Feedback Control"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Control–feedback–abort loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control%E2%80%93feedback%E2%80%93abort_loop"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"}]

## Feedback Control

Based on the search results, here's an overview of feedback control:

### Definition

A feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller.(no content)A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

### How It Works

In closed loop control, the control action from the controller is dependent on the process output. The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Key Components

A control loop consists of the process sensor, the controller function, and the final control element which controls the process necessary to automatically adjust the value of a measured process variable (PV) to equal the value of a desired set-point (SP).

### Practical Example

In the case of a boiler analogy, this would include a thermostat to monitor the building temperature, and thereby feed back a signal to ensure the controller maintains the building at the temperature set on the thermostat.

### Advantages

Control systems that include some sensing of the results they are trying to achieve are making use of feedback and can adapt to varying circumstances to some extent.(no content)Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov Function"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov–Schmidt reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov%E2%80%93Schmidt_reduction"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Lyapunov vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_vector"},{"title":"Conley's fundamental theorem of dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conley's_fundamental_theorem_of_dynamical_systems"}]

## Lyapunov Function

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

### Purpose and Applications

For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.(no content)A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state, and is typically defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

### Construction

There is no general technique for constructing Lyapunov functions for ODEs, though in many specific cases the construction is known, such as quadratic functions for systems with one state or solutions of particular linear matrix inequalities for linear systems.

### Stability Conditions

If the equilibrium point is isolated, the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally positive definite, and the time derivative is locally negative definite, then the equilibrium is proven to be locally asymptotically stable.

### Related Concepts

In control theory, a control-Lyapunov function (CLF) is an extension of the idea of Lyapunov function to systems with control inputs. Additionally, important tools for the verification of input-to-state stability (ISS) are ISS-Lyapunov functions.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov–Schmidt reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov%E2%80%93Schmidt_reduction"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Lyapunov vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_vector"},{"title":"Conley's fundamental theorem of dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conley's_fundamental_theorem_of_dynamical_systems"}]

## Lyapunov Function

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

### Purpose and Applications

For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.(no content)A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state, and is typically defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

### Construction

There is no general technique for constructing Lyapunov functions for ODEs, though in many specific cases the construction is known, such as quadratic functions for systems with one state or solutions of particular linear matrix inequalities for linear systems.

### Stability Conditions

If the equilibrium point is isolated, the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally positive definite, and the time derivative is locally negative definite, then the equilibrium is proven to be locally asymptotically stable.

### Related Concepts

In control theory, a control-Lyapunov function (CLF) is an extension of the idea of Lyapunov function to systems with control inputs. Additionally, important tools for the verification of input-to-state stability (ISS) are ISS-Lyapunov functions.

Web search results for query: "Observer state estimation control"

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"},{"title":"Observer pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_design_pattern"},{"title":"Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalman_filter"},{"title":"State estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?redirect=no&title=State_estimation"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_(physics)"}]

I've completed the web search for "Observer state estimation control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Why State Observers Are Needed

In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.(no content)Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.

## Key Observer Types

Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

Notable examples include:
- The Kalman filter is an efficient recursive filter estimating the internal state of a linear dynamic system from a series of noisy measurements.
- Nonlinear high-gain observer methods are available that converge quickly without the peaking phenomenon. For example, sliding mode control can be used to design an observer that brings one estimated state's error to zero in finite time even in the presence of measurement error.

## Separation Principle

In control theory, a separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system.

Based on the search results, here's information about Actor-Critic Reinforcement Learning:

## Overview

Actor-critic methods can be understood as an improvement over pure policy gradient methods like REINFORCE via introducing a baseline.(no content)Many actor-critic methods belong to the category of generalized policy iteration algorithms, and in recent years, actor–critic methods have been proposed and performed well on various problems.

## How It Works

The critic must learn alongside the actor, and the critic is learned by value-based RL algorithms.(no content)The critic can be learned by any value function approximation method if estimating the state-value function, or by Q-learning or SARSA if estimating the action-value function.

## Common Variants

Several popular actor-critic algorithms exist in practice:

- Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (A3C): Parallel and asynchronous version of A2C.
- Soft Actor-Critic (SAC): Incorporates entropy maximization for improved exploration.
- Other mainstream model-free RL algorithms include Deep Q-Network (DQN), Trust Region Policy Optimization (TRPO), Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG), Twin Delayed DDPG (TD3), and Distributional Soft Actor-Critic (DSAC).

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Pseudospectral optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudospectral_optimal_control"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"},{"title":"Unscented optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unscented_optimal_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"PROPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PROPT"},{"title":"Witsenhausen's counterexample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witsenhausen's_counterexample"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what optimal control is:

## Definition

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.

## Applications

It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research.(no content)For example, the dynamical system might be a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, and the objective might be to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure. Or the dynamical system could be a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment; the controls in this case could be fiscal and monetary policy.

## Key Concepts

Optimal control deals with the problem of finding a control law for a given system such that a certain optimality criterion is achieved. A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.

## Solution Methods

The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Historical Background

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.

## Solution Methods

The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Historical Background

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

Here are the search results for "Adaptive Control":

## Adaptive Control Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences from Other Control Methods

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Categories of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

## Modern Applications

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.(no content)A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Zero dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_dynamics"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Dead-beat control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead-beat_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear Dynamics (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_Dynamics_(journal)"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Nonlinear Control Systems:

## Definition

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle and are often governed by nonlinear differential equations. Some distinctive properties of nonlinear systems include:

- They do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity).
- They may have multiple isolated equilibrium points and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, chaos.

## Analysis and Design Methods

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, including limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.

## Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system, where a building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off", it does not have the fine control in response to temperature differences that a proportional (linear) device would have.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Paper Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes new methods)

**Extracted 9 Key Technologies and Methodologies:**

1. **Artificial Neural Network** - Method (proposes adaptive NNs for unknown dynamics)
2. **State Observer** - Method (proposes adaptive NN state observer)
3. **Feedback** - Concept (uses output feedback control)
4. **Backstepping** - Method (uses backstepping technique for controller development)
5. **Lyapunov Function** - Concept (uses barrier Lyapunov functions for state constraints)
6. **Nonlinear Control** - Method (addresses strict-feedback nonlinear systems)
7. **Optimal Control** - Method (proposes optimal controllers with barrier cost functions)
8. **Actor-Critic Algorithm** - Method (uses actor-critic architecture)
9. **Adaptive Control** - Method (proposes adaptive NN-based control)

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully

The triples_output.json file has been updated with all entities properly categorized with their Wikipedia links and relevance explanations. The paper demonstrates a sophisticated integration of control theory (backstepping, Lyapunov stability), machine learning (neural networks), and optimization (optimal control with actor-critic methods) to solve the challenging problem of controlling nonlinear systems with state constraints and unknown dynamics.
